awd_titl_txt: Workshop on Arithmetic and Topology Over Global Fields
awd_abstract_narration:
The award will fund participation in a workshop titled "Arithmetic and topology over global fields," to be held October 7-9, 2022 at the University of Wisconsin-Madison.  This workshop will focus on developments at the interface between two different fields of math, number theory and topology.  The workshop will bring together early-career mathematicians from both subjects in order to spur further progress at this already-active boundary between fields. Funding will be concentrated on graduate students, postdocs, and researchers without other federal funding.  Our conference also focuses on inclusiveness in the math community by inviting many high-profile early-career female mathematicians, and will apply to set up the conference in cooperation with the Association for Women in Mathematics.  A webpage with up-to-date information about the workshop can be found at this link: https://sites.google.com/view/october-workshop/home. 

Questions pertaining to monodromy have been highly influential on recent work in areas like rational and integral points on varieties, special points, unlikely intersections, statistics of Selmer groups, etc. Many fundamental conjectures about motives or algebraic cycles are also deeply connected to monodromy. This conference aims to bring together experts on various topological aspects of varieties defined over arithmetic bases to give talks to a wider audience consisting of graduate students, postdoctoral researchers and other mathematicians working in arithmetic geometry.  We also aim for the workshop to be an environment for the participants at all levels to meet and talk in person, and seek new collaborations, creating impact throughout the field.  We hope that the diversity of topics and talks given by senior participants in the workshop will provide a fantastic opportunity for the junior participants to learn about new developments and questions in the field. We provide a 2-hour poster session for the junior participants, especially graduate students, to present their projects and results to experts and peers.  Our advertisement and recruitment will prioritize graduate students and early-career researchers, who stand to benefit the most from an introduction to this quickly-moving area.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award was used to fund the workshop "Arithmetic and topology over global fields", held in the University of Wisconsin, Madison, from October 7th 2022 until October 9th 2022. The purpose of the workshop was to gather together experts and junior researchers to discuss recent advances in the use of topological methods in number theory.

Our workshop had 10 speakers (Amina Abdurrahman, Maria Fox, Michael Groechenig, Aaron Landesman, Daniel Litt, Nicole Looper, Abhishek Oswal, Padmavathi Srinivasan, Boya Wen, and Criag Westerland), and several junior participants (including undergraduate students, graduate students and postdocs). The speakers gave excellent and well received talks which were accessible to even junior participants.

 

The conference opened with talks by Fox, Srinivasan, and Litt, followed by a graduate student poster session and an ice cream social. The second day saw talks by Landesman, Oswal, Groechenig, Looper and Wen, interspersed with breakfast and lunch (provided by the workshop). The final day had talks by Westerland and Abdurrahman.

 

The subject of our workshop is by its nature interdisciplinary, drawing on techniques in number theory, algebraic geometry, and topology, which makes meetings between people with overlapping but non-identical expertise really important for progress. Our speakers had a wide range of research intersts, leading to several productive conversations and discussions between talks.

 

Junior participants (graduate students and postdocs without grants) were prioritized for travel funding, and we were able to fund every participant's accomodation. We made efforts to recruit participants from underrepresented groups by advertising our workshop to email lists (such as the Women in Numbers mailing list and MIT's STAGE mailing list) and social media servers (such as the POINT -- People Online in Number Theory -- discord server). The poster session provided graduate students with a platform to talk about their research both to peers and to experts in the field.
